p: The material used to produce the films was mangarito starch ( Xanthosoma mafaffa Schott, Dourados, Brazil) composed of 7.91 ± 0.11% moisture, 0.15 ± 0.06% ash, 0.03 ± 0.03% lipids, 2.24 ± 0.02% protein, 89.58 ± 0.13% carbohydrates, and 25.78 ± 0.49% amylose, obtained from rhizomes harvested in the experimental crop 2017–2018 of the Medicinal Plants Garden of the Federal University of Grande Dourados, Dourados, Brazil, commercial copaiba oil (Verde Nattus, Maringá, Brazil) purchased at Mundo Verde in Dourados/MS, and glycerol (Dynamic, Indaiatuba, Brazil). Gelatin type A, Bloom 240, GAP 6 (Gelita ® from Brazil, Cotia, Brazil), gum arabic (Dynamic, 85%, Indaiatuba, Brazil), and hydrochloric acid (LS Chemicals, 37%, Ribeirão Preto, Brazil) were used in the production of microparticles. For the antimicrobial activity, the following bacterial strains were used: Bacillus subtilis (ATCC WDCM 00003), Staphylococcus aureus (ATCC 25923), Escherichia coli (ATCC WDCM00013), Pseudomonas aeruginosa (ATCC 27853), Enterobacter aerogenes (ATCC 13048) and Salmonella typhimurium (ATCC WDCM 00031) donated by Microbiology Laboratory from National Service for Industrial Training (Dourados, Brazil), Brain Heart Infusion (BHI) broth (Prodimol Biotechnology, Belo Horizonte, Brazil), Mueller–Hinton agar (Kasvi, São José dos Pinhais, Brazil), dimethyl sulfoxide solvent (Vetec, 99.9%, Duque de Caxias, Brazil), chloramphenicol antibiotic (Lb Laborclin, 30 μg, Pinhais, Brazil), and a paper filter disc (J. Probal, Qualy, pores 14 μm, São José dos Pinhais, Brazil).
